docs.title: Welcome to Nhost
docs.description: Nhost is an open-source, real-time, server-less backend platform for building reliable apps that scale with your business.

docs.title: Create your app
docs.description: Let's create a simple todo-app using Nhost. In a todo-app, a user should be able to create list items for their account (CRUD) and not have anyone else see them (permissions).

docs.title: JavaScript client
docs.description: In the previous section, you used the Hasura Console to fetch a list of todos. Now, you will write a small JavaScript client to interact and retrieve todos from your Nhost app.

docs.title: Set permissions
docs.description: In the previous section, you could fetch the todos because the admin role is enabled by default when using Hasura Console. When building your applications, you want to define permissions using roles that your users can assume when making requests.

docs.title: Define schema
docs.description: To implement an app for managing a todo list, let's ensure we have database tables for storing todos and users.

docs.title: Upgrade from v1 to v2
docs.description: Upgrading from Nhost v1 to v2 requires database schema and Hasura metadata changes.

docs.title: Authentication
docs.description: Nhost provides a ready-to-use authentication service, integrated with Nhost JavaScript SDK. This makes it easy to build login flows with multiple sign-in methods.

docs.title: Sign in with Facebook
docs.description: Follow this guide to sign in users with Facebook with your Nhost App.

docs.title: Sign-in methods
docs.description: Nhost supports a variety of sign-in methods:

docs.title: User management
docs.description: Users are saved in the database in the auth.users table and are accessible via the GraphQL API.

docs.title: Database
docs.description: Every Nhost app comes with a Postgres database. Postgres is the world's most advanced open-source relational database and the most popular SQL database among developers. The database is hosted with Amazon RDS.

docs.title: GraphQL
docs.description: Every Nhost app has its own autogenerated GraphQL API. The GraphQL API is based on the tables and columns in the Postgres database and is instantly available. It's Hasura GraphQL engine that powers the GraphQL API.

docs.title: Permissions
docs.description: The GraphQL API is protected by a role-based permission system based on access tokens. Permissions are handled on a per-table basis in Hasura Console.

docs.title: The Nhost Platform
docs.description: - Database

docs.title: Environment variables
docs.description: Environment variables are key-value pairs configured outside your source code. They are used to store environment-specific values such as API keys.

docs.title: GitHub integration
docs.description: You can connect your Nhost app to a GitHub repository. When you do this, any updates you push to your code will automatically be deployed.

docs.title: Overview
docs.description: Documentation for other platform features:

docs.title: Nhost CLI
docs.description: Nhost CLI lets you run Nhost's development environment locally on macOS, Linux and Windows.

docs.title: Event triggers
docs.description: Event triggers are HTTP webhooks that fire on a database event, such as insert, update, or delete. These events are usually a result of GraphQL mutations, but any other database operation will also fire events.

docs.title: Serverless Functions
docs.description: Nhost gives you the option to run serverless functions on the following runtimes:

docs.title: Storage
docs.description: Nhost stores and serves files of any type in your backend.

docs.description: Run nhost help in your terminal to get a detailed listing of all available commands.
